ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Some insight into what "science" is, both in theory and practice.

I learned how to analyze scientific studies for their credibility and break down each section for clarity. In addition, I learned more about the process of scientific thinking and how scientists make descisions.
In this class, I learned how to be skeptical when it comes to scientific data and the dangers that arise from drawing binary conclusions.
Critical thinking for evaluating scientific studies and planning our own, how to make the most of college
Different perspectives on scientific research and how to go about it

This course develops skills necessary to be able to interpret statistics and science and construct a high validity scientific paper. I learned the most about a relatively new field in data analysis called causal inference.
I developed skills in scientific inquiry, the scientific process, data analysis, and critical thinking.

This course teaches about causation and the scientific method. From time to time it felt like an extended first week of a science high school class. This course is very redundant in content and the vagueness of the course title shields it from accountability.

I learned a lot about how scientists use a variety of methods to study the world around us, and how it is important to know the processes of these studies in order to properly inform ourselves to use that information wisely.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I felt some of the readings were a bit repetitive and I wish we spent more time reading some scientific literature.

Strengths: skills are pretty applicable to reading scientific studies, course is pretty organized, and prof is an expert in his field.  Weaknesses: definitions and concepts are sometimes really abstract and hard to grasp, actual class time is a little disorganized and I'm not actually sure what was covered in each one, and more guidance on the final project could have been given.

The strengths of this course were the small class size, ability to communicate sufficiently with the professor, and the respect for all opinions to be brought to the table without judgement. The weaknesses were the format of each class (they were always the same, and this became monotonous), the length of readings sometimes, and the students' lack of understanding how some concepts or words were defined. It was as if the definitions always changed from class to class, so this made it very confusing.
very discussion based which i loved, but sometime the discussions made it difficult to nail down precisely what we were supposed to be taking away from a given reading

The course structure is a bit loose, and the meetings tend to be less discussion and more lecture, but that has more to do with student participation than professor teaching. More thorough teaching of the material before discussion might remedy the issue.
Too much reading and could use more discussion but very interesting and applicable information, the exams were all very straightforward and I like having specific goals.
A strength was the culture of engagement and discussion created by Professor Fernandez-Duque. Our class grew very close over the semester. I cannot think of a glaring weakness of the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are interested in what goes into scientific research, than yes. Particularly if you have an interest in biological anthropology.
Yes, it is a good introductory science course which build skills used in other classes.

Yes, in the end I would recommend this course to another student who is looking to complete a science requirement. I think that in order to succeed though, the student should meet with the professor a lot and communicate with his/her peers in the class.
Yes, the professor is a great person to get to know and the structure of the course is perfect for a first year seminar
Yes, this is a great course to improve scientific literacy. It is kinda like being exposed to the tips and tricks of the scientific trade.

I do not want to sound bias but I would advise fellow students to steer away from this course. The readings are redundant and uninsightful. Compared to other courses at Yale, this class has much less to offer. In this class you learn how to memorize a bunch of facts and vomit them in the midterm without gaining any intellectual value. I felt like we did not move forward from the first thing we learned: P values suck, here is why. Participation by fellow students was practically 0 because the content of this class is simply not engaging. Overall, if you are looking for an easy science credit I would definitely advise you to keep looking because this class has a lot of insipid work. The professor is an expert in primates but in spite of a conscious effort, one fails to see the link between the method he uses to study primates and the methods he teaches us in this course. I certainly did not feel the enthusiasm I felt with all my other classes.

I would, because it allows students, especially those who may not be going down a STEM path, to use the means of science ethically and effectually in their lives, especially as decisions must be made by policy makers with those tools.
